Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Persistence, entrainment, and function of circadian rhythms in arctic ground squirrels
Award.AbstractNarration: The Earth's light-dark (LD) cycle is the strongest cue for entraining circadian rhythms and is considered the primary driver for the emergence and evolution of endogenous clocks. In polar regions, however, photoperiod exhibits extreme annual variation culminating with the sun remaining above or below the horizon for extended periods. Without a defined LD cycle, some arctic residents lose daily organization of behavior and physiology, and it has been hypothesized that the molecular clockwork that drives circadian rhythms may be weak or absent in arctic vertebrates. This study tests the hypothesis that persistence of circadian organization in some arctic mammals is adaptive because it allows organisms to minimize thermoregulatory costs. Specifically, the investigators will examine persistence, entrainment, and function of circadian rhythms in the arctic ground squirrel (AGS) during the continuous daylight of the active season and the continuous dark of hibernation. Four research objectives span from molecular and neurobiological mechanisms to physiological, behavioral and ecological adaptation: (1) determine when circadian rhythms are exhibited during the annual cycle of free-living AGS and establish if the onset of rhythmicity in spring coincides with first exposure to light, (2) determine if circadian rhythms persist in the master clock of AGS during hibernation by measuring patterns of clock gene expression in the suprachiasmatic nuclei (SCN) of the brain, (3) determine if AGS entrain circadian rhythms to daily changes in light quality or intensity, and (4) investigate patterns of re-entrainment and the function of rhythms in the arctic summer by experimentally phase-shifting free-living ground squirrels and measuring metabolic costs of nocturnal activity. Whether circadian rhythms persist during hibernation is contentious. Transcription and translation are thought to be globally suppressed during deep torpor and the only study to examine clock-gene expression within the SCN during multi-day torpor found no evidence of oscillations. However, circadian body temperature rhythms have been observed in some studies of captive ground squirrels during torpor and timing of arousals has been hypothesized to be controlled by a circadian clock. Persistence of oscillations in clock-gene expression in the SCN would support existence of tissue-specific mechanisms for translational control of a subset of genes relevant to survival during hibernation. In contrast, expression of daily rhythms may not be compatible with hibernation; SCN function and or output may be inhibited to prolong torpor. This study integrates research and learning by (1) training post-docs and students from three universities in ecophysiological studies in the laboratory and field, (2) inclusion of Alaska Natives in research through participation in the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program, and (3) increasing K-12 students' engagement in research by participating in Teacher Research Experience programs. Results of research will be disseminated locally in classroom presentations and nationally through the University of Alaska media relations team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the persistence, entrainment, and function of circadian rhythms in a small arctic resident, the arctic ground squirrel, during the continuous daylight present during the active season and during continuous dark of the 6-8months of hibernation when ground squirrels are sequestered in a burrow. We found that circadian (~24h) rhythms of body temperature and cycling of clock-gene protein products in the master circadian clock stopped being expressed during hibernation in this species, and the timing of spontaneous arousals from torpor is unlikely to be controlled by the master circadian clock. We also found that persistent daily rhythms in free-living arctic ground squirrels are maintained through a circadian system that readily entrains to (aligns with) the polar day, during which the sun never sets. Yet their circadian systems remain insensitive to entrainment by rapid light–dark transitions, which these animals generate naturally as they exit and re-enter their burrows multiple times each day. We also found that arctic ground squirrels did not show ‘jet lag’, the slow realignment of circadian rhythms induced by the inertia of an intrinsically stable master circadian clock. We suggest this may be due to the low expression of a small molecule, arginine vasopressin, in the master clock of arctic ground squirrels, as vasopressin is associated with inter-neuronal coupling and robust rhythmicity.

Intellectual Merit: In the absence of a well-defined light-dark cycle, some arctic residents lose their daily organization of behavior and physiology, and it has been hypothesized that the molecular clockwork that drives circadian rhythms may be weak or absent in arctic vertebrates. However, our study demonstrates arctic species can have strong persistent circadian (diurnal) rhythms throughout the arctic summer. Additionally, we found that despite having circadian systems with apparently exquisite sensitivity to subtle changes in lighting across the polar day, when the sun never sets, arctic ground squirrels are resistant to entraining (shifting) their circadian timing in response to square wave light-dark cycles. We suggest this differential sensitivity likely occurs in most semi-fossorial mammals that spend significant time below-ground in burrows (or in other dark environments) as their circadian systems must not respond to light-dark transitions caused by their own behavior. Whether circadian rhythms persist during hibernation has long been contentious. Both transcription and translation are thought to be globally suppressed during deep torpor suggesting that clock-gene cycling could not persist. However, circadian body temperature rhythms have been observed in some, but not all, studies of captive ground squirrels during torpor and timing of arousals has been hypothesized to be gated by a circadian clock. Our finding that clock-gene proteins in the master clock do not continue cycling in arctic ground squirrels is consistent with the only other study to examine clock-gene expression within the master clock during multi-day torpor that also found no evidence for persistent oscillations. These results suggest the function of the master clock is arrested, or disrupted, during hibernation. Further, it had previously been assumed that the induction of C-Fos, a marker of neuronal cell activation, in the master clock was associated with circadian function during this arousal from low body temperature. Our study revealed that the underlying mechanisms of C-Fos expression during arousal is not associated with circadian clock and differs from light stimulus. Thus, the master circadian clock appears unlikely to function in triggering arousals from low body temperature.

Broader Impacts: This study integrated research and learning by training post-docs and graduate students from three universities and departments of biology and psychology in neurobiological, ecophysiological and behavioral studies of a hibernating mammal in experimental and natural settings and by providing opportunities for undergraduates to participate in laboratory and field experiments. We increased the general public and K-12 students' understanding of and engagement in polar research through curation of a special exhibit at the University of Alaska Museum "Hibernation and the Science of Cold". During its tenure at the U of A museum, 16,529 people visited the exhibit, including 505 K-12 students on school trips and 50 K-12 teachers from PolarTREC and a CryoConn conference. We also conducted outreach directed at K-12 students by participating in PolarTREC, a program in which teachers from the United States spend 3-6 weeks participating in hands-on field research experiences in polar regions. While in the field, the three PolarTREC teachers we hosted connected with classrooms and the public using internet tools including online journals, message boards, photo albums, and “PolarConnect" videoconference calls. After the field experience, teachers continued to share their experience in classrooms and with the public through public presentations, scientific conferences, and teacher workshops. We also collaborated with teachers in developing curricular materials for middle school and high school students that utilized biologging data from arctic ground squirrels.
